mn12:0.2: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar
mn12:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying outside the city of Vesālī in a woodland grove west of the town.
mn12:2.1: Now at that time Sunakkhatta the Licchavi had recently left this teaching-and-discipline.
mn12:2.2: He was telling a crowd in Vesālī:
mn12:2.3: “The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge-and-vision worthy of the noble ones.
mn12:2.4: He expounds a teaching that he is worked out by reasoning and consideration, out of his own wit.
mn12:2.5: And his teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it is taught.”
mn12:3.1: Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
mn12:3.2: He heard what Sunakkhatta was saying.
mn12:3.6: Then he wandered for alms in Vesālī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and informed him of the matter.
mn12:4.1: “Sāriputta, Sunakkhatta, that inept man, is angry.
mn12:4.2: His words are spoken out of anger.
mn12:4.3: Thinking he criticizes the Realized One, in fact he just praises him.
mn12:4.4: For it is praise of the Realized One to say:
mn12:4.5: ‘His teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it is taught.’
mn12:5.1: But there is no way that inept man Sunakkhatta will infer about me through the Dhamma:
mn12:5.2: ‘That Blessed One is an Arahant, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
mn12:6.1: And there is no way that inept man Sunakkhatta will infer about me through the Dhamma:
mn12:6.2: ‘That Blessed One wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying himself and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unimpeded through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.’
mn12:7.1: And there is no way that inept man Sunakkhatta will infer about me through the Dhamma:
mn12:7.2: ‘That Blessed One, with the divine ear that is purified and superhuman, hears both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.’
mn12:8.1: And there is no way that inept man Sunakkhatta will infer about me through the Dhamma:
mn12:8.2: ‘That Blessed One understands the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with his own mind.
mn12:8.3: He understands mind with passion as “mind with passion,”
mn12:8.4: and mind without passion as “mind without passion.”
mn12:9.1: There are these ten powers of a Realized One that the Realized One possesses. With these he claims supremacy, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
mn12:10.1: Firstly, the Realized One understands as it is the possible as possible, and the impossible as impossible.
mn12:10.2: Since he understands this as it is, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims supremacy, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

mn12:17.1: Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand births; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and displeasure, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I reappeared somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and displeasure, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I reappeared here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
mn12:17.2: Since he understands this as it is, this is a power of the Realized One. …
mn12:18.1: Furthermore, with the divine eye that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees beings passing away and reappearing—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how beings reappear according to their actions. ‘These beings engaged in misconduct by way of body, speech, and thought. They found fault with the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they reappear in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These beings, however, engaged in good conduct by way of body, speech, and thought. They did not find fault with the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they reappear in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with the divine eye that is purified and superhuman, he sees beings passing away and reappearing—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how beings reappear according to their actions.
mn12:18.2: Since he understands this as it is, this is a power of the Realized One. …
mn12:19.1: Furthermore, the Realized One, with the destruction of the influxes, lives having entered upon the liberation by mind and liberation by understanding that is devoid of influxes, having for himself comprehended and realized it right in the present experience.
mn12:19.2: Since he understands this as it is, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims supremacy, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

mn12:37.3: Then some time later I see that they have indeed reappeared in hell, where they feel exclusively unpleasant feelings, sharp and severe.

mn12:44.1: Sāriputta, I recall having lived a renunciate life consisting of four factors.
mn12:44.2: I used to be a fervent ascetic, the supreme fervent ascetic. I used to be a rough-liver, the supreme rough-liver. I used to be a shunner, the supreme shunner. I used to be a recluse, the supreme recluse.
mn12:45.1: And this is what my fervent asceticism was like. I went naked, ignoring conventions. I licked my hands, and did not come or stop when asked. I did not consent to food brought to me, or food prepared specially for me, or an invitation for a meal.
mn12:45.2: I did not receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where food for distribution is advertised; or where there is a dog waiting or flies buzzing. I accepted no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drank no beer.
mn12:45.3: I went to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
mn12:45.4: I fed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
mn12:45.5: I ate once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. I lived committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
mn12:45.6: I ate herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. I survived on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
mn12:45.7: I wore robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
mn12:45.8: I tore out hair and beard, committed to this practice.
mn12:45.10: I squatted, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
mn12:45.11: I lay on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns my bed.
mn12:45.12: I was committed to the practice of immersing in water three times a day, including the evening.
mn12:45.13: And so I lived committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
mn12:45.14: Such was my practice of fervent mortification.
mn12:46.1: And this is what my rough living was like.

mn12:47.2: I would step forward or back with great care; my kindness was established for even a drop of water, thinking:
mn12:47.3: ‘May I not injure any little creatures on unclear ground.’
mn12:48.1: And this is what my seclusion was like.
mn12:48.2: I would plunge deep into a wilderness region and stay there.
mn12:48.3: When I saw a cowherd or a shepherd, or someone gathering grass or sticks, or a lumberjack, I would flee from forest to forest, from thicket to thicket, from valley to valley, from uplands to uplands.
mn12:48.5: So that I would not see them, nor they me.
mn12:48.6: I fled like a wild deer seeing a human being.
mn12:48.10: Such was my practice of seclusion.

mn12:49.3: Such was my eating of most gruesome things.

mn12:52.12: Eating so very little, my body became extremely emaciated.
mn12:52.13: Due to eating so little, my limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a corpse,
mn12:52.14: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,
mn12:52.15: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,
mn12:52.16: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
mn12:52.17: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.
mn12:52.18: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.
mn12:52.19: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.
mn12:52.20: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.
mn12:52.21: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

mn12:57.4: For if I had roamed amidst the gods of the pure abodes, I would not have returned to this world again.
mn12:58.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:58.3: But it is not easy to find a reappearance that I have not previously [experienced], except for the gods of the pure abodes …
mn12:59.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:59.3: But it is not easy to find an abode where I have not previously abided, except for the gods of the pure abodes …
mn12:60.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:60.3: But it is not easy to find a sacrifice that I have not previously performed in all this long time, when I was an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
mn12:61.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:61.2: ‘Purity comes from serving the sacred flame.’
mn12:61.3: But it is not easy to find a fire that I have not previously served in all this long time, when I was an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
mn12:62.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:62.2: ‘So long as this gentleman is youthful, young, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life he will be endowed with perfect lucidity of understanding.
mn12:62.3: But when he is old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—he will lose his lucidity of understanding.’
mn12:62.4: But you should not see it like this.
mn12:62.5: For now I am old, elderly, and senior, I am advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life. I am eighty years old.
mn12:62.6: Suppose I had four disciples with a lifespan of a hundred years. And they each were perfect in memory, range, retention, and supreme lucidity of understanding.
mn12:62.7: Imagine how easily a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow would shoot a light arrow across the shadow of a palm tree.
mn12:62.8: That is how extraordinary they were in memory, range, retention, and supreme lucidity of understanding.
mn12:62.9: They would bring up questions about the four establishments of recollection again and again, and I would answer each question. They would remember the answers and not ask the same question twice.
mn12:62.10: And they would pause only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness. But the Realized One’s teaching of the Dhamma, words and phrases pertaining to the Dhamma, and wit in replying to questions would not at all be exhausted.
mn12:62.11: And at the end of a hundred years my four disciples would pass away.
mn12:62.12: Sāriputta, even if you have to carry me around on a cot, there will never be any deterioration in the Realized One’s lucidity of understanding.
mn12:63.1: And if there is anyone of whom it may be rightly said,
mn12:63.2: ‘A being not subject to muddledness has arisen in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans, it is of me that this should be said.’”
mn12:64.1: Now at that time Venerable Nāgasamāla was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.
mn12:64.2: Then he said to the Buddha:
mn12:64.3: “It is incredible, Bhante, it is amazing!
mn12:64.4: While I was listening to this exposition of the teaching my hair stood up!
mn12:64.5: What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”
mn12:64.6: “Well then, Nāgasamāla, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Hair-raising Discourse’.”
mn12:64.7: That is what the Buddha said.
mn12:64.8: Pleased, Venerable Nāgasamāla delighted in what the Buddha said.
